The described tool has legitimate capabilities for converting AI chat transcripts with documented security measures (zero-JS output, atomic file writes, opt-in network behavior).

content.user_title: Convert AI Chat Share Links to Markdown
content.value_statement: Saving AI chat transcripts often breaks code blocks and creates messy filenames. This tool converts share links from ChatGPT, Gemini, Grok, and Claude into clean Markdown and HTML with preserved formatting and syntax highlighting.
actual_capabilities: Convert share links from ChatGPT, Gemini, Grok, and Claude to Markdown
Preserve code fences with language detection and syntax highlighting
Generate deterministic, collision-proof filenames from conversation titles
Create static HTML output with inline CSS and zero JavaScript
Publish exports directly to GitHub Pages with one command
Handle Claude.ai Cloudflare protection using your Chrome session
limitations: Requires public share links (Claude.ai uses your browser session)
Provider layouts may change over time affecting selectors
Markdown and HTML exports require share link to be accessible

faq.question: Which AI platforms are supported?
faq.answer: ChatGPT, Gemini, Grok, and Claude share links are all supported. Each has optimized extraction logic.

faq.question: Do I need a Claude.ai login for all platforms?
faq.answer: No. Only Claude.ai requires your Chrome session. ChatGPT, Gemini, and Grok use public share links.

faq.question: What file formats does it produce?
faq.answer: Two files are created: Markdown (.md) with preserved code fences and static HTML (.html) with inline styling.

faq.question: Is my data sent to external servers?
faq.answer: Only the share URL is fetched. GitHub publishing is opt-in and uses the official gh CLI for authentication.

faq.question: What happens if code blocks are not detected?
faq.answer: The tool uses provider-specific selectors with fallback chains. Report issues if certain content is missed.

faq.question: How is this different from copy-pasting?
faq.answer: Copy-paste often breaks code formatting and loses language hints. This tool preserves fences, syntax highlighting, and generates clean deterministic filenames.
